Hall_of_the_Scribes.artifact_site: Lishkat ha-Gazit - discovered beneath the Western Wall (first-century layers)
Hall_of_the_Scribes.what_it_shows: A dedicated room with clay seal impressions indicating sealed scroll containersâ€”the physical space where the official biblical scrolls were kept.
Hall_of_the_Scribes.evidence: Sealed Clay Bullae (seal impressions) from the Temple Mount area

Sealed_Clay_Bullae.what_it_shows: Priestly seals (e.g., 'the priest of the Most High') used to mark sacred documents.
Sealed_Clay_Bullae.evidence: Priestly seals found in archaeological excavations

Papyrus_Fragments.what_it_shows: Demonstrate that paper-like writing material was used in Jerusalem in the late-first-century CE, confirming that scrolls could have been stored in the Temple.
Papyrus_Fragments.evidence: Papyrus fragments recovered from City of David

Qumran_Cave_4.what_it_shows: Over 500 scrolls, many of which are biblical and liturgical. While Qumran itself was a community site, the dating (c. 200 BCE-70 CE) and textual affinities with Temple-style texts suggest a shared library culture among Jewish elites.
Qumran_Cave_4.evidence: Over 500 scrolls including biblical and liturgical texts
